November 2013
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Blake's illustrations to works by William Hayley, including his Essay on Sculpture, the broadside ballad Little Tom the Sailor, The Triumphs of Temper, The Life and Posthumous Writings of William Cowper, and The Life of George Romney. We are also republishing Blake’s etched and engraved illustrations to Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley (1802) and Hayley’s Ballads (1805). The designs and engraved texts of both sets of Ballads illustrations, as well as the new material now being published, are fully searchable.
In late 1799, William Hayley was seeking an engraver to illustrate his poem Essay on Sculpture. Possibly on the advice of the sculptor John Flaxman, Hayley commissioned Blake to produce three plates. In July 1800, Blake spent much of July working on the final plate, an engraving of Hayley’s deceased son, Thomas, in Hayley’s library in the coastal village of Felpham, West Sussex. During these weeks, Hayley persuaded Blake to relocate from London to Felpham to work on a number of graphic projects. Disenchanted with his failure to secure commercial engraving work in London, Blake enthusiastically took up Hayley’s offer.
The works now published and republished include all of Blake’s commercial engravings executed for Hayley during the three-year period Blake and his wife Catherine spent in Felpham. In addition, the Blake Archive is publishing two more engravings Blake worked on for Hayley after the Blakes had returned to London in September 1803. These plates were commissioned to illustrate Hayley’s The Life of George Romney (1809). Only one of these plates, Sketch of a Shipwreck after Romney, was included in the published biography. The other, a portrait engraving of Romney, was rejected and, until very recently, has not been seen since the 1939 Blake exhibition in Philadelphia.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
May 2009
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of Blake's etchings and engravings of his illustrations to Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley (1802) and to the 1805 edition of Hayley's Ballads. These nineteen plates, all but two of which are based on Blake's own designs, are presented in our Preview mode, which provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
While Blake was resident in Felpham on the Sussex coast, beginning in 1801, his new patron William Hayley began to write a series of ballads to be illustrated by the artist-engraver. These were published in 1802 as quarto numbers, each with a frontispiece, headpiece, and tailpiece by Blake. As the general title page indicates, the poems all deal with "Anecdotes Relating to Animals." In his preface, Hayley states that his plan was to issue one ballad a month "and to complete the whole series in fifteen Numbers." The letterpress text was printed by the Chichester printer Joseph Seagrave; the plates were printed by Blake and his wife Catherine on their own rolling press. Although two book dealers, P. Humphry and R. H. Evans, were selected to sell the ballads, most copies seem to have been sold by Hayley to his friends. Sales were less than brisk and the project ceased after only four ballads were issued. Blake designed and executed twelve plates, including a frontispiece for the general title page and a tailpiece to the preface, both issued with the first ballad. Two further plates were engraved by Blake after designs on antique gems (Plates 5 and 11, the tailpieces to "The Elephant" and "The Lion").
We are also publishing a closely related work, Blake's five illustrations for the 1805 edition of Hayley's Ballads. In January 1805, Hayley contacted the London bookseller Richard Phillips about publishing a new, octavo edition of the ballads. Blake began to execute engravings for this edition no later than March and completed five plates by June. For this 1805 volume, Hayley added twelve ballads to the four published in 1802. Blake engraved new, smaller plates of his designs for three of the 1802 ballads (Plates 1-3) and both designed and engraved new illustrations for two of the additional ballads (Plates 4-5). Blake and Phillips were to "go equal shares ... in the expense and the profits" (Blake's letter to Hayley of 22 January 1805, Erdman page 763), but it is unlikely that Blake made any profit. Robert Southey's mocking review of Hayley's poems and Blake's illustration to "The Dog" (Plate 1) appeared in the Annual Review for 1805.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator, etcher,engraver,printer. Plates 5 and 11 are based on antique gems and thus were not designed by Blake. Blake and his wife Catherine printed the plates on their own rolling press.

Thomas Hayley delineator. Plate 11, a copy of an antique gem, is signed "T. H. del:". This indicates that "T. H." (very probably William Hayley's son, Thomas, who died in 1800) made a drawing of the gem; this drawing was the basis for Blake's engraving.

imprint.publisher: William BlakeThe title page specifies that the ballads were "Published, by William Blake." They were "Printed by J. Seagrave, and sold by him and P. Humphry; and by R. H. Evans, Pall-Mall, London, for W. Blake, Felpham" (title page).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central image appears in an arched frame above a text panel. A nude male with short, curly hair sits below a tree in the center of the design. The trunk of the tree divides into several branches with sparse leaves visible, particularly above and to the right of the figure. The ground below is likely covered with grass, particularly in the lower right corner of the image. The male figure rests on a stone or mound of earth. This is probably Adam in Eden, shown in the act of naming the animals. A second stone or mound appears to the left of the tree. The figure's eyes are raised and he may look at the eagle above. He faces forward with both legs bent; his left foot may be raised on tiptoe. The figure's left arm is bent with the elbow resting on his left knee; his left palm is turned up with the fingers spread slightly. His right arm is down and he touches the mane of the lion below. The lion lies on the ground and faces right in profile with its head down and possibly resting on its front paws. Its right eye is raised and the lion may look at the figure above. Its mouth is open with the tongue extended; the lion may lick the right foot of the male figure. The lion has a distinct mane of curly fur and its tail extends below. A snake or serpent with a spiky crest on its head appears on the ground below the central male figure. The snake's body faces right with its head turned to the left in profile. Its mouth is open with the tongue extended. Shading along the length of its body suggests scales. The snake's body forms four loops. Two birdsprobably dovessit or lie on the ground below the snake. The bird to the left faces right while the bird to the right faces left. Their beaks are touching. The bird to the left spreads its wings slightly. A horse with a visible mane and tail stands to the right of the central male figure. The horse faces forward and slightly right with its head turned down and to the left. The horse's front left leg is bent and raised off the ground. Both front hooves are visible. A sheep with curved horns stands in the lower right corner of the image. The sheep faces left and grazes with its head down. The sheep's eyes are closed or perhaps cast downward. The sheep's left foreleg is visible with the hoof clearly distinguishable. A peacock stands on a rock or mound of earth to the left of the central figure. The peacock is seen from behind with its head turned to the right; it may look at the male figure. The peacock's tail feathers extend downward. A rooster stands on a rock or mound of earth to the left of the central figure. The rooster faces right in profile with its head turned up. Its beak is open with the tongue extended; it is likely crowing. The rooster's tail feathers form a plume and a spiky comb appears on its head. A winged insect, possibly a moth, flies in the upper left corner of the image, facing left. A bird sits on a slender branch at the left border of the image, below the rooster. The bird faces left with its head turned to the right. The shape of its beak suggests that this may be a parrot. A horned ox or cow appears to the left of the central figure. Lines on the cow's body (to the left and right of the rooster) suggest long hair or fur. The animal is likely standing and faces to the right. Its head is down and its mouth is open slightly; it may be grazing. An eagle with outstretched wings sits or rests in the tree directly above the central male figure. The eagle's feathers are clearly visible. The eagle faces forward with its head turned up and to the right. Horizontal lines in the upper portion of the design indicate sky.

lg.l: Their strength, or speed, or vigilance, were giv'n
In aid of our defects. In some are found
Such teachable and apprehensive parts,
That man's attainments in his own concerns
Match'd with th' expertness of the brutes in theirs
Are oft times vanquish'd and thrown far behind.
Cowpers Task
Book VI.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An elephant stands in the center of the design with its right foreleg bent and raised off the ground. The elephant faces right with its head turned up. Its mouth is open with the tusks extend upward. Its right eye is raised and it likely looks at the figure above. The elephant holds and lifts a dark-skinned male with its trunk wrapped around the figure's waist. The figure is partly nude and wears short pants and a cloth turban. His legs extend down and to the left; the left leg crossed in front of the right, and only the figure's left foot is visible. The figure's right arm is down at his side with the palm turned down. His left arm is bent and he touches the elephant's trunk with his left hand. The figure faces forward with his head turned left in profile; his expression suggests fear or surprise. The setting is likely a city street in India; the ground may be bare earth or is perhaps covered with grass. A tent-like structure, described in the poem as a gardener's shed, appears to the right of the elephant. In this context, the shed would appear to serve as a market stall. The shed's sloped roof is supported by at least two visible posts. A plate or shallow basket rests on the shed's counter; the plate is piled with fruit or other food, including two pineapples. Two wicker baskets with distinct handles stand on the ground below the shed; both are filled with round, possibly leafy fruits. A wall or building appears in the background to the right of the elephant. An arch appears in the middle of the structure, likely representing a door or open entryway. At least three posts or pillars support a small domed roof above the structure; a spire rises above the roof. A building with three domes on the roof appears above and to the left of the elephant. Each dome is topped with a spire. Etched lines in the upper portion of the design indicate a sky with clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is an oval. A house apparently made of stone or brick stands in the right portion of the design. The building is at least two stories tall with a ledge or balcony supported above the first floor by two pillars. This ledge or balcony also serves as a roof for the porch below. An arched entryway is visible between the pillars; the door stands open. A leafy potted plant is visible through the open doorway. Two pilasters appear to the left and right of the arch. A single open window is visible on the second story of the house. A second window is visible through the open doorway. The building is raised on a step or other plinth-like platform. A dark-skinned male stands on a ledge or balcony above the first floor of the house. The figure is partly nude and wears short pants and a cloth turban. His left leg is bent and enters the open window; his right leg is extended backward and to the left. His right arm is bent upward; his right hand and left arm are not pictured. The figure faces right with his head turned forward, towards the viewer. He may look down and to the left towards the tiger below. The man's lunging posture suggests that he is fleeing the beast. The tiger, which may be pursuing the man, stands facing right in a crouched position with its head down. Its mouth is open and its two canine teeth are visible. The tiger's eyes are raised and it looks at the figure on the ledge above. The ground below may be bare earth or is perhaps covered with grass. The trunk of a tree appears in the foreground along the right border of the image. Two leafy branches split off from the main trunk. A snake-like vine wraps around the trunk of the tree and the upper branch. Seven leaves appear along the vine. A tendril forms two loops suggestive of a spiral to the left of the tree trunk. Four large leaves appear below the tree along the lower border of the design. Indeterminate leafy vegetation appears to the left of the house; it may represent a jungle or forest. Two palm trees with distinct trunks and arching leaves appear above the tiger; a third palm tree appears at the left border of the image. A group of four buildings with domed roofs appear above the tiger. Each roof is topped with a spire. A triangular structure below the rightmost dome may represent a tent. A column or tower rises above the trees to the left of the domes; the structure is topped with a palmette or other decorative design. Etched lines in the upper left portion of the design indicates a sky filled with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Frontispiece to The Eagle, Ballad the Second, Object 6 (Bentley 466.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned female kneels on a cliff in the upper portion of the design. She is identified as Jessy in Hayley's poem, "The Eagle." Jessy is the mother of the child below. The figure's legs are bent and her right foot is visible below her gown. She bends slightly right and her arms are raised nearly horizontally with the palms turned out towards the viewer. The figure's head is down and her long hair trails to the right. Her eyes are cast down and she looks at the eagle and child below. An eagle stands above a nest in the center of the design. Both talons are clearly visible. The eagle's wings are outstretched and have distinct feathers. The eagle faces forward with its head turned down and to the right. A male child or infant sits or reclines in an eagle's nest in the center of the design. The child is gowned and has short, curly hair. Both feet are visible below his gown. His left arm is bent and his left hand rests on the ground with the palm turned down; he is likely supporting his weight. The child's right arm is bent upward with the palm turned up; he touches the underside of the eagle's head with his right hand. The eagle's nest is made of straw laid on top of wooden sticks. An animal skull and perhaps part of a rib cage appear in the nest to the right of the child.
